title: Questions and Thoughts on Libraries and AI
content:
Three Questions about Libraries and AI

Question 1: Do libraries capture the true value of AI?

When we librarians talk about AI, we usually associate it with robotics and digital content – most of the current AI projects in libraries tend to have a focus on these two topics. For example, AI can make robots smart, it can automatically generate metadata for images and books, and it can colorize archived photos etc.. While there is nothing wrong with this, it makes us blindfolded from the true value of AI. We do not think of AI in the way of improving library performance.

Should libraries care more about this? A recent research shows that AI has the potential to improve library performance by 87% if we put libraries in the same bucket of bookstores and Amazon Books (the retail category in the image below). Suppose the estimate becomes reality, libraries could get further marginalized in the future if we do not start transforming now.

The major advantage of AI lies in its ability to help humans identify hidden patterns and trends in big data. The size and magnitude of big data are simply too far fetched for the capacity of human brains. We need machines’ assistance to handle the overflow of information in many domains and areas. For example, if a library collects the reference desk data at a very granular level and feed years of the data in an AI model, AI might generate unexpected finings and predictions that a 20-year reference librarian might not be able to discover and conclude. What kind of benefits can be derived from this? Combined with AI’s findings and human expert’s judgement, a library can train staff with more specific goals in mind, assign reference shifts by popular locations and by peak time and peak days, change library hours to work better with customers, pinpoint promotions to customer’s interests, redesign the library space (shelves, signs etc. ) as needed, develop programs around customers’ pain points etc.. AI and machine learning can make libraries more efficient, responsive and proactive. I am looking forward to see practical use cases of AI in library operations in the near future.

Question 2: Are libraries AI friendly?

The answer is probably no.

Financially, the current grant and budget plan in libraries do not work well with new technology projects. For an AI project, we probably need budget to cover the long-term subscription cost with cloud servers, cloud storage, cloud computing, api calls etc.. So a new financial model similar to that of electronic resources needs to be established first if libraries want to test the water of AI.

Content wisely, libraries are caught offhanded.

Are your library’s website and other public information machine readable and machine friendly? Does your library’s website have an API? Does your catalog have an API? Does your library’s calendar have an API, or at least, an RSS feed? When adopting AI, machines will need all kinds of relevant resources for data analytics. There should be a quick and easy way for machines to get the most up-to-date information, as well as historical data, without much human intervention. To use the NAO robot project I am leading at my library as example, we were trying to develop the robot so people can ask a question like “is the library open?” You would assume it’s a simple task that can be realized in a few lines of code, but turns out the solution is quite intertwined. Our main library website does not have an API yet, so the machine needs to take the slow process to check multiple places. First it reads the regular schedule webpage and capture the information. Then it reads the events RSS feed to see if there is any planned or unexpected closures at any branches on a specific day. Finally, it consolidates both findings for the output.

Question 3: Have libraries curated qualified big data to train a library centered AI?

The answer is yes and no.

Libraries have plenty statistics data, which is good, meaning we are in a good shape if we want to develop a prediction model similar to the stock market.

However, the piece of data missing is the raw human-centered data. In the reference desk instance I gave above, this means libraries should record the very questions asked by customers. Before AI, saving this type of data was a waste of time, but if we want to train a library centered AI, we certainly need granular human-centered data in many places. An analogy to this would be if we want to develop a Natural Language Processing(NLP) model, we have to rely on an existing dataset to let the machine learn how different people narrate questions differently. A lot of NLP data set are from sources like Wikipedia, CNN, Daily Mail, Gutenberg books, Twitter, Reddit etc.. I run into this issue of lacking raw data when I started to develop the Nao robot to have the question and answer features similar to Alexa and Siri. Michael Hibben from Roanoke County Library, who is leading a project to develop a Pepper robot, run into the same issue as well. Michael and I have no other options but to take up the manual process of slowly creating an artificial training data set. This means we have to manually come up with a bunch of questions, and sometimes answers as well, to train the AI model. This is not the ideal solution. Now if a library already has a web-based reference service and the questions are archived, they probably have a head start to develop a library-centered chatbot. That being said, libraries probably would never want to develop a completely AI based chatbot. A fully AI-based chatbot will have the opacity issue (see definition of opacity issue in the next section) by generating nonsense, misleading or stupid answers. This is certainly against the library’s goal of providing accurate and authoritative information to its customers.

Some other thoughts on AI

I am an advocator of artificial intelligence despite its shortcomings and I can tell you why by sharing my thoughts on some commonly acknowledged challenges created by AI. These challenges are best summarized as opacity, neutrality and stupidity by Professor Pellio, Director of the European Centre for Living Technology.

Opacity means that most of the times, how AI produces an output is a black box to humans, including its very own developers. This is because modern AI algorithms like the deep neuron network uses thousands of iterations and millions of parameters to determine the outputs. Stupidity means sometimes AI can easily get fooled and produce stupid outputs. These do not prevent AI to be useful. My take on this is that we should only use AI as an assistant or a tool to augment human abilities. We should never put our full trust in a tool. Humans know to question and doubt, while the current generation of AI is pretty single-minded and narrowly focused on a specific task in a specific domain. My other take is that AI will cause less controversial and become more useful if it is kept at the backend, similar to the ILS technology, in
libraries.

Neutrality is a much tougher issue. Why AI is biased? AI is not neutral because it gets its knowledge from data generated by humans. Hence, it inherits human prejudices and discriminations recorded in the source data. A good analogy is a library’s collection, which is biased in the same way too. I bet there is bad data like improper words or biased comments or unacceptable attitudes in some books in your library’s collection. Something widely accepted 50 years ago might become unacceptable now, and we can think of lots of examples. AI’s bias is rooted in humans, so this is not a new problem but unfortunately, new technology like AI may amplify it exponentially. Is there an ultimate solution to this? Should we hide the dark side of humans when we train a machine? If yes, how do we cherry pick and censor the training data set? And by who’s standards? Here I would like to use a quote by Latoya Perterson, cofounder of the blog Racialicious, from the book Algorithms of Oppression: “…racism API is tweaked to be context specific, but it’s all the same source code. The key to its undoing is recognizing how many of us are ensnared in these same basic patterns and modifying our own actions. “

title: The story of "literacy" in American Libraries Direct
content:
Lou, D. (2019) The The story of “literacy” in American Libraries Direct, American Libraries Magazine. Available at: https://americanlibrariesmagazine.org/latest-links/story-literacy-american-libraries-direct/ (Accessed: March 15, 2019).

The article Examining the word “literacy” on AL Direct, December 18, 2018, raised my interest in examining the word “literacy” in a different way. As was the article’s author Georgina Trebbe, I am quite amazed by the popularity of the word “literacy” which is deeply rooted in libraries. Likewise, I want to have a better understanding of how the usage of “literacy” changed over the years. Then an interesting idea occurred to me: how about examining the word “literacy” in all issues of American Libraries Direct by applying the skills in “data literacy”, “digital literacy” and “information literacy”?

My little pet project started from scraping the American Libraries Direct Archive by writing a Python script, and saving those data in csv files. The most important data is the issue date, article title, and article summary. For the purpose of the project, I excluded miscellaneous information that are not an article in these issues.

Then I used Python Pandas to import the whole data set.

df = pd.read_csv('Data/american_libraries_summaries.csv', index_col=0)

Fig. 0: Screenshot of scraped data from AL Direct Archive

Frequency of “literacy” and its pairings

The next step is to use Python’s natural language processing package NLTK to trace the word “literacy” in all archived issues. I would like to get the frequency distribution of the word in AL Direct Archive. (Frequency distribution generates raw counts of a given word in a text.) I used the word “information”, “program” and “digital” as “controlled variables” in my experiment. I will explain why these specific words are selected later on.

Before calculating the frequency distribution, I developed a set of code to normalize all words in content. This is a critical step to ensure that I will get more accurate result. My script should not be case sensitive when counting the occurrences of a given word. What’s more, it should take plural words like “programs” into account. Then I run the code to get the frequency distribution.

cfd = nltk.ConditionalFreqDist(
​ (year, word)
​ for year in range(2006,2019)
​ for word in [singular(w.lower()) for w in annualSummaries(year, df)])
modals = ['literacy', 'information', 'program', 'digital']
years = range(2006,2019)
years_data = tabulate(cfd, modals,years)

Fig. 1 shows that the frequency of occurrence for the word”literacy” is relatively stable. (The frequency of occurrence is computed by dividing the frequency distribution with the total count of words in a given text.) The “literacy” line has a slight uptick compared to the declining lines of the other three words. However, on average, “literacy” is still the least used word among all four words here. It merely contributes about 0.047% to AL Direct Archive throughout the years. (See Table 1)

You will notice the frequency distribution numbers are strikingly higher across the board from 2006 and 2014 (see Fig.2 and Table 1) . It is due to content cutdown in each issue since Oct 7, 2014, which is an unexpected discovery for my pet project. I will explain this in details later on.

Fig. 2: Frequency distribution for words “literacy”, “information”, “program” and “digital

The frequency distribution and the frequency of occurrence data give us a nice overview of how low profile the word “literacy” is. But we still do not know in what contexts this word is get used.

To shed some light on this inquiry, I chose to use and modify NLTK’s concordance function. By default, the concordance functions shows us every occurrence of a given word, together with some context. I modified the function to return all the words used next to (before and after) every occurrence of a given word. Basically, this will help me to find all the literacy pairings. Then I drew word cloud graphs to visually display the data. I also computed the frequency of the pairing words to get accurate results. (See Fig. 3)

Fig. 3: Word cloud for pairing words of “literacy” in AL Direct from 2006 to 2018

As you can see from Fig. 3 and Table 3, the top three pairing words are “information”, “digital” and “program”. That is why I picked these as “controlled words” in the frequency of occurrence calculation.

From Table 3 and Table 4 , we can see that except in 2012 and 2018, “information literacy” is always the most popular term among all literacy topics. Apparently, we librarians holds “information literacy” dearly.

  • Information Literacy: the ability to use information and communications technologies to effectively locate, evaluate, determine relevancy, synthesize, and use information ethically.

I think “literacy skills”, “early literacy” and “family literacy” all belong to a same category, despite their slight differences, they all emphasize building skills required for reading and writing:

  • Literacy skills: all the skills needed for reading and writing.
  • Early Literacy: what children know about reading and writing before they actually read or write.
  • Family literacy: home literacy activities that provide literacy skill-building opportunities for young children while enhancing literacy skill development in all members of the family.

And this category is an important and constant theme as shown by data. From 2006 to 2015, it always had spot on the top three literacy pairings list. Noticeably, “early literacy” appeared on the list in 5 out of 13 years.

“Literacy program” was popular from 2007 to 2009. But since 2011, it never actually managed to come back to the top three list again. It is possible that instead of discussing general literacy programs, librarians switched to focus on specific ones.

  • Literacy program: library programs to promote literacy.

“Digital literacy” maintained popular from 2011 throughout to 2013, and afterwards, it tuned down.

  • Digital literacy: the ability to use information and communication technologies to find, evaluate, create, and communicate information, requiring both cognitive and technical skills.

“Financial literacy” shows the libraries’ rapid response to the economic crisis around the time. It was listed as the top three literacy topics in both 2014 and last year, 2018.

  • Financial literacy: the possession of the set of skills and knowledge that allows an individual to make informed and effective decisions with all of their financial resources.

Besides financial literacy, in recent years, “health literacy” also started to catch libraries’ attention.

  • Health literacy: the degree to which individuals have the capacity to obtain, process, and understand basic health information and services needed to make appropriate health decisions.

AL Direct’s Content Cutdown Strategy

I made an unexpected discovery when scraping the AL Direct Archive. I noticed that there are roughly two different styles for all the archived pages. This implicates that some time in the past AL Direct updated its online appearance. The style modification also indicates the underlying change of the content strategy. By glancing over the size of data in different years, I made the conclusion that the update might have taken place toward the end of 2014 or the beginning of 2015. The annual data size abruptly dropped from 2.9M in 2014 to less than 1M in 2015 (see Fig. 1).

Fig. 1: Data size of AL Direct Archive by year

A closer look of the number of articles per month agrees with this conclusion. In October 2014, this number shrank to almost a third of that of the previous month. (see Fig. 2)

Fig. 2: Number of articles per month from 2006 to 2018

Let’s zoom in to the data in October 2014, and we notice the number of articles per issue plunged on Oct 7, 2014, and it maintained that low level onwards. (see Fig. 3)

Fig. 3: Number of articles per issue in October 2014

This content cutdown strategy is a smart move if we consider the unpopularity trend of “mailing list” since 2014 as Google Trends told us. (see Fig.4)

Fig. 4: Trend of “mailing list” from Google Trends

I am sure the downsizing of AL Direct helped many librarians to better manage their professional readings every week. Before, a subscriber might have felt overwhelmed every week when he/she clicked and opened the long mailing list containing 75 articles on average (at the peak, it was 182 articles to read in the week of July 2, 2010 and July 3, 2013). Now, he/she only has an average of 12 articles to go through in every seven days.
